abstract.text: A UIKit view controller that manages a SwiftUI view hierarchy.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: object when you want to integrate SwiftUI
views into a UIKit view hierarchy. At creation time, specify the SwiftUI
view you want to use as the root view for this view controller; you can
change that view later using the
property. Use the hosting controller like you would any other view
controller, by presenting it or embedding it as a child view controller

SwiftUI-PageImage-card.png.alt: A black Swift logo on a swirly blue and purple background.

Unifying-your-app-s-animations-PageImage.alt: A conceptual illustration of a disclosure indicator, shown animating frame by frame from its collapsed position to its expanded position.

abstract.text: Declare the user interface and behavior for your app on every platform.
A content configuration suitable for hosting a hierarchy of SwiftUI views.
A UIKit view controller that manages a SwiftUI view hierarchy.
Creates a hosting controller object from the contents of the specified
archive.
Creates a hosting controller object from an archive and the specified
SwiftUI view.
Creates a hosting controller object that wraps the specified SwiftUI
view.
Sets the screen edge from which you want your gesture to take
precedence over the system gesture.
The preferred status bar style for the view controller.
The animation style to use when hiding or showing the status bar for
this view controller.
The preferred interface style for this view controller.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the view controller prefers the
home indicator to be hidden or shown.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the view controller prefers the
status bar to be hidden or shown.
The root view of the SwiftUI view hierarchy managed by this view
controller.
The safe area regions that this view controller adds to its view.
Calculates and returns the most appropriate size for the current view.
The options for how the hosting controller tracks changes to the size
of its SwiftUI content.
Notifies the view controller that its view has been added to a
view hierarchy.
Notifies the view controller that its view is about to be added to a
view hierarchy.
Notifies the view controller that its view will be removed from a
view hierarchy.
Options for how a hosting controller tracks its content’s size.
Create a consistent UI animation experience across SwiftUI, UIKit, and AppKit.
A type that represents part of your app’s user interface and provides
modifiers that you use to configure views.
Learn how to incorporate SwiftUI views into a UIKit app.
An object that manages a view hierarchy for your UIKit app.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The interface an app extension uses to respond to a request from a host app.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A protocol that a class must adopt to allow appearance customization using the [`UIAppearance`](doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIAppearance) API.
A set of methods for adapting the contents of your view controllers to size and trait changes.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
Methods for adding objects to your state restoration archives.
A set of methods that makes the iOS interface environment available to your app.
The protocol you adopt to restore an object’s state from a user activity.
A type that calls your code in reaction to changes in the trait environment.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A type whose values can be implicitly or explicitly copied.
